<topcClas>Race relations - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Religion and values - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Social attitudes and behaviour - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Ethnic minorities - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The main aim of this project was to see how well post-devolution Scotland is succeeding in accommodating both nationalism and multiculturalism at the same time. A further and more specific objective was to increase understanding of ethnic minority perspectives on post-devolution Scotland. <br> <br> The study covers minority perspectives on nationalism and multiculturalism in post-devolution Scotland, in particular:<ul><li>their views on the principles of devolution/independence, and on the performance of Holyrood (the location of the Scottish Assembly)</li><li>their perceptions and recent experiences of harassment, their perceptions of change, and the extent to which they attribute this change explicitly to devolution/Holyrood</li><li>whether they are at ease with living in Scotland, whether they feel more or less at ease now than in the past, and where they see their long-term future</li><li>to what extent they can personally identify with Scotland and with Scottish national symbols</li><li>their inhibitions, e.g. whether they feel they can 'speak their mind' about Scotland and things Scottish or have to be careful not to offend the majority</li></ul>The study also includes majority perspectives (in England and in Scotland) on the Muslim minority and (in Scotland only) on the English immigrant minority also. The views of minorities and majorities about each other are also compared. Finally, Scottish elite perspectives have been used to cover these minority/majority relations and other similar divisions in Scottish society, especially the historic sectarian divide. <br> <br> This mixed methods data collection consists of:<ul><li>1,510 original telephone survey interviews with 751 English immigrants and 759 ethnic Pakistanis within Scotland (data for each group held in separate files)</li><li>transcripts of twelve focus group discussions with English immigrants and ethnic Pakistanis within Scotland</li></ul>In-depth interviews were also conducted during the project with 27 members of the Scottish elite, but these are not included in the data collection for reasons of confidentiality. <br> <br> A set of special questions for this project were also fielded in the <i>Scottish Social Attitudes, 2003</i> (SSA) and <i>British Social Attitudes, 2003</i> (BSA) studies (held at the UK Data Archive (UKDA) under SNs 5076 and 5235 respectively). Data from these questions have not been included separately here, but users are advised to order SNs 5076 and 5235 in addition to this dataset to obtain the SSA/BSA data.<br> <br> A full description of the data and account of the project appears in Hussain, A.M. and Miller, W.L. (2006) <i>Multicultural nationalism: Islamophobia, Anglophobia and devolution</i>, Oxford: Oxford University Press. This publication should always be cited when the data are used.<br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Topics covered include nationalism, multiculturalism, devolution in Scotland and questions of identity.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate>Focus group interviews with ethnic Pakistanis were conducted between 3 September 2002 and 7 January 2003, the English immigrant focus group interviews were conducted between 9 January and 12 March 2003, and the telephone survey took place between July 2003 and January 2004.</collDate>         <nation>Scotland</nation>         <geogUnit>Scottish Parliamentary Constituencies</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>English immigrants (born in England and living in Scotland) plus numerous persons living in households containing an English immigrant, and ethnic Pakistanis (by self-definition) resident in Scotland, plus a very few persons living in a household containing an ethnic Pakistani (not enough for analysis). The interviews were carried out in areas where the particular minority were known, from the <i>Census 2001</i> to be especially numerous. For confidentiality reasons the exact locations of the focus groups have not been disclosed.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Cross-sectional (one-time) study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>The SSA 2003 and BSA 2003 are part of repeated cross-sectional series.</timeMeth>         <sampProc>English immigrants: random sampling of phone numbers in areas where <i>Census 2001</i> indicated high levels, then selection by filtering questions.<br>Ethnic Pakistanis: sampling of Pakistani names from phone directories in similar high level areas, then selection by filtering questions.</sampProc>         <deviat>751 English immigrants, 759 ethnic Pakistanis, 12 focus group discussions</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Telephone interview; Transcription of existing materials</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>No weighting used, but for analysis purposes the data may be weighted to age x gender statistics from the <i>Census 2001</i>.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. See <a href=http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/conditions.aspx>terms and conditions of access</a> for further information.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>         <disclaimer>Users of these data are also advised to order SN 5076 <i>Scottish Social Attitudes, 2003</i> and SN 5235 <i>British Social Attitudes, 2003</i>, and to purchase the publication cited in the 'Abstract' section above.</disclaimer>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relStdy>5076 Scottish Social Attitudes Survey, 2003 </relStdy>       <relStdy>5235 British Social Attitudes Survey, 2003 </relStdy>       <relPubl>Hussain, A.M. and Miller, W.L. (2006) <i>Multicultural nationalism: Islamophobia, Anglophobia and devolution</i>, Oxford: Oxford University Press. This publication should always be cited when the data are used.<br></relPubl>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
